http://schema.org/subtitleLanguage.description: Languages in which subtitles/captions are available, in IETF BCP 47 standard format.

http://schema.org/image.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

http://schema.org/eventStatus.description: An eventStatus of an event represents its status; particularly useful when an event is cancelled or rescheduled.

http://schema.org/workPerformed.description: A work performed in some event, for example a play performed in a TheaterEvent.

http://schema.org/aggregateRating.description: The overall rating, based on a collection of reviews or ratings, of the item.

http://schema.org/potentialAction.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

http://schema.org/inLanguage.description: The language of the content or performance or used in an action. Please use one of the language codes from the IETF BCP 47 standard. Supersedes language.

http://schema.org/workPresented.description: The movie presented during this event.

http://schema.org/review.description: A review of the item. Supersedes reviews.

http://schema.org/duration.description: The duration of the item (movie, audio recording, event, etc.) in ISO 8601 date format.

http://schema.org/location.description: The location of for example where the event is happening, an organization is located, or where an action takes place.

http://schema.org/workFeatured.description: A work featured in some event, e.g. exhibited in an ExhibitionEvent. Specific subproperties are available for workPerformed (e.g. a play), or a workPresented (a Movie at a ScreeningEvent).

http://schema.org/offers.description: An offer to provide this item—for example, an offer to sell a product, rent the DVD of a movie, perform a service, or give away tickets to an event.

http://schema.org/endDate.description: The end date and time of the item (in ISO 8601 date format).

http://schema.org/description.description: A short description of the item.

http://schema.org/previousStartDate.description: Used in conjunction with eventStatus for rescheduled or cancelled events. This property contains the previously scheduled start date. For rescheduled events, the startDate property should be used for the newly scheduled start date. In the (rare) case of an event that has been postponed and rescheduled multiple times, this field may be repeated.

http://schema.org/mainEntityOfPage.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described. See background notes for details. Inverse property: mainEntity.

http://schema.org/subEvent.description: An Event that is part of this event. For example, a conference event includes many presentations, each of which is a subEvent of the conference. Supersedes subEvents.

http://schema.org/attendee.description: A person or organization attending the event. Supersedes attendees.

http://schema.org/superEvent.description: An event that this event is a part of. For example, a collection of individual music performances might each have a music festival as their superEvent.

http://schema.org/startDate.description: The start date and time of the item (in ISO 8601 date format).

http://schema.org/recordedIn.description: The CreativeWork that captured all or part of this Event. Inverse property: recordedAt.

http://schema.org/performer.description: A performer at the event—for example, a presenter, musician, musical group or actor. Supersedes performers.

http://schema.org/videoFormat.description: The type of screening or video broadcast used (e.g. IMAX, 3D, SD, HD, etc.).

http://schema.org/sameAs.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

http://schema.org/additionalType.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

http://schema.org/typicalAgeRange.description: The typical expected age range, e.g. '7-9', '11-'.

http://schema.org/image.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

http://schema.org/description.description: A short description of the item.

http://schema.org/potentialAction.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

http://schema.org/mainEntityOfPage.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described. See background notes for details. Inverse property: mainEntity.

description: A screening of a movie or other video.
title: ScreeningEvent
